dlgPart.npc_text:
“I thank you for your intervention, traveler. It's always pleasing to see wickedness punished and virtue rewarded. What brought you here?” asks the Oracle – an ancient, wizened man with a deeply lined face.
He looks at you, first with his good eye, then with the empty socket that would be his left. It’s a well-practiced movement that makes you feel as if the dead socket is looking into your very soul.

dlgAnsw.text: “I seek an ancient temple. I was told that I might be able to find some clues to its whereabouts here.”

dlgPart.npc_text:
The Oracle – an ancient, wizened man with a deeply lined face – slowly gets up when you approach and looks at you, first with his good eye, then with the empty socket that would be his left. It’s a well-practiced movement that makes you feel as if the dead socket is looking into your very soul. The other men and women of the group watch intently from various relaxed positions around you.
“What do you seek here, traveler?” he asks.

dlgAnsw.text: “I seek an ancient temple. I was told that I might be able to find some clues to its whereabouts here.”

dlgPart.npc_text: END
“Your eye...,” whispers the Oracle in disbelief. “The stories are true...”

dlgAnsw.text: “Step aside, old man.” Approach the arch.

dlgPart.npc_text: “May the Gods blessing be upon you.”

dlgAnsw.text: Remove the eye patch.
Leave.

dlgPart.npc_text: The Oracle stares at you with a mix of wonder and fear.

dlgAnsw.text: Leave.

dlgPart.npc_text: END - narrate Ignoring

dlgPart.npc_text: “You stand upon holy ground. Many are the answers that may be found here ... if the gods be willing. What is your name?”

dlgAnsw.text: “<charname>.”
“Of little relevance to my inquiry.”
Remove the eye patch.

dlgPart.npc_text: “Then you have traveled far for naught. None here possess the knowledge you seek.” He smiles sympathetically.

dlgAnsw.text: [etiquette][charisma]“My name is <charname>. I didn't mean to cause offense, o holy one. I hope you will accept my most sincere apologies and aid me on my quest.”

“Suffice to say, I have doubts.”

dlgPart.npc_text: He looks genuinely puzzled. "The legends, they tell of how the First of the Magi sought out the gods in our time of need. They came forth and..."

dlgAnsw.text: Interupt. "...did some things of which the details can't be agreed upon from one telling to the next. I find the legends to be contradictory and distinctly lacking in provable facts. Look around you, there are no gods."
“Of course they did. If you don't mind, let's skip the history lesson and jump straight to business.”

dlgPart.npc_text: "A <man/woman> who doubts the gods, yet comes seeking guidance from one who speaks with them?"

dlgAnsw.text: "I came here seeking information about an ancient temple. I did not know I would find a holy man and his disciples."

dlgPart.npc_text: "Then perhaps the gods have something to tell you? Maybe you are not here by accident. Nor me."

dlgAnsw.text: "It's hard to believe in something that is never here. The legends say the gods came forth in our time of need and if so, they left us with precious little. I look around and see the scorched land we've inherited, a people in need, and yet I see no gods."

dlgPart.npc_text: He ponders you for a moment then begins slowly. "Yesterday, when I woke, I had no belief in <charname>. All day long I had no belief in <him/her> and, had one of my acolytes come to me during the day and said to me, 'Master, what of <charname>?', I could have said 'Fool look around you, there is no <charname>'. Yet today, you stand before me."

dlgAnsw.text: "What's your point, old man?"
"Well then, I remain unconvinced but reserve the right to change my mind should the gods stumble out of the Waste someday to pay me a visit. Good enough for you?"
"Fair enough. So, can you help me find the temple or not?"

dlgPart.npc_text: "Just that though today may hold questions, tomorrow may bring clarity."

dlgAnsw.text: "And while we wait for this divine certainty?"

dlgPart.npc_text: He leans forward, tapping his chest with one knobby finger and smiling. “Faith can fill the gap between the doubt and the proof.”

dlgAnsw.text: “I could bring myself to envy that on some days. So, what do our ‘gods’ have for me and my search?”
“Unfortunately, this gap needs more than faith. Let us complete this charade so that I may hear what you know of the temple.”

dlgPart.npc_text: “Then, let us see if the gods have ears for us this day, <charname>." He waits patiently then looks from you to a small empty offering box that sits on a rough stool to his left. A tiny bell hangs gleaming from a hooked piece of iron that's been driven into the top of the stool, and a short metal striking rod hangs by a string next to it. The acolytes watch in silence.

dlgAnsw.text: Offer 5 imperials and ring the bell.
Offer 50 imperials and ring the bell.
Offer 100 imperials and ring the bell.
"Sorry, old man, not today." Leave.

dlgPart.npc_text:
The bell's high pitched note rings out long and clear against the vast silence around you. It’s perfect note steadily diminishes until only a pregnant tension hangs in the air. After several seconds of intense silence the Oracle speaks.
"<He/She> who is hungry, but can only afford crumbs, remains hungry." He stands calmly and patiently, measuring you with his gaze.

"Sorry, old man, not today." Leave.

dlgPart.npc_text:
The bell's high pitched note rings out long and clear against the vast silence around you. That perfect sound steadily diminishes until only a pregnant tension hangs in the air. After several seconds of intense silence the Oracle begins to chant softly and slowly. The words, if that is what they are, sound as gibberish to you.
He begins to rock in time with the cadence of his chant, gradually increasing speed. At one point you are certain you hear your name amongst the twisted syllables but it is quickly carried away by the rapid flow of the chant.
The Oracle’s one eye rolls back until nothing but the white is visible and he begins to shake violently. The chanting and tremors reach a sudden apex, then ... stop suddenly and completely as the old man flicks a handful of fine dust into the air from a pouch at his side. His eye flits forward and studies the cloud of silt as it lazily settles to the ground. The muffled gasps and exhalations of the acolytes ripple around you.
Without focusing on you he calmly speaks, “The gods attend us. Put forth your query...”

dlgAnsw.text: “I seek an ancient temple.”

dlgAnsw.text: “I seek an ancient temple.”

dlgPart.npc_text: A moment passes as relief slowly spreads across the old man’s face. “The gods are aware of your quest and they have blessed its course. You are on the proper path and no enemy may prosper that would stand between you and the temple. You will reach your destination.”

dlgAnsw.text: “But, where do I go from here?”

dlgPart.npc_text: “Have no fear, the gods desire for you to reach the temple and they shall lead your way. Three signs they will send. Watch closely and with eyes of faith, for one time only will each sign be revealed.”

dlgAnsw.text: “This wasn't very helpful.”

dlgPart.npc_text: “Not a very faithful beginning to a faith based search. Take care that you not miss the first sign. I must rest now.” The Oracle collects the offering into a small pouch and moves to take a seat within the cool shade of the arch.

dlgAnsw.text: Leave.

dlgPart.npc_text: The Oracle begins collecting your offering into a large pouch at his side. He pauses and sighs. “The gods’ ways, they are ... mysterious,” he says almost apologetically. “It can be frustrating even for one such as me. Tell me, why do you seek the temple?”

dlgAnsw.text: “To uncover its mysteries.”
“To pray on the holy ground.”
“To plunder its depths.”
“My reasons are my own.”

dlgPart.npc_text: “Then take hope that the gods have blessed your journey. They seem to have an interest in your prying into those mysteries.”

dlgAnsw.text: "Do you have time for a few more questions?"
Leave.

dlgPart.npc_text: He nods approvingly. “This pleases me <charname>... and the gods as well. Look to Inferiae for the first sign. They honor the old ways there and the gods smile upon them.”

dlgAnsw.text: "Do you have time for a few more questions?"
Leave.

dlgPart.npc_text: He breathes deeply. “Take care <charname>. The gods lead thy way but, though they are not spiteful, they may find your motivations unworthy in the end.”

dlgAnsw.text: "Do you have time for a few more questions?"
Leave.

dlgPart.npc_text: “Then may they be sufficient for carrying you the distance.”

dlgAnsw.text: "Do you have time for a few more questions?"

dlgPart.npc_text: The old man waves away the lingering acolytes who disperse to their mundane chores and then motions for you to follow him to the shade of the arch.

dlgAnsw.text: “What do you know of this place? And the arch?”
“Do you not live in fear here in the Wastes?”

dlgPart.npc_text:
“It is a holy place, chosen by the gods in the early days for communicating with those who were most worthy. In those days, the gods spoke more freely and frequently. Maybe we were more worthy then, who can know? Can you imagine living at that time, <charname>? Conversing directly with the deities? Being judged worthy enough to bathe in that divine light that would herald the gods’ coming? It was here!” He opens his arms broadly as if to embrace his surroundings. “It was all here...
“Our ancestors entrusted us with keeping vigil and watching for the next coming. Our stories and prophecies have been passed down from one Oracle to the next. One early prophecy speaks of the day in which the gods will return and that three signs will foretell their arrival. Divine light shining once again upon,” he pats the stones upon which leans, “this arch, will be the first sign.”

dlgAnsw.text: “What are the other signs?”

dlgPart.npc_text: “The first sign alone was revealed to the early Keepers. They were tasked with sending swift messengers to the Magi, but the Magi are long gone. We alone shall be the first to greet the Gods upon their return.”

dlgAnsw.text: “Why do you think the gods left us?”
“How is it that you can communicate with the gods even now?”
“Do you not live in fear here in the Wastes?”
Leave.

dlgPart.npc_text: “As I’ve said, the gods’ ways are beyond our understanding. We can not grasp them any more than we can pluck stars from the night sky. But they are not completely gone.”

dlgAnsw.text: “How is it that you can communicate with the gods even now?”
“Do you not live in fear here in the Wastes?”
Leave.

dlgPart.npc_text: “We may all communicate with the gods. Even you spoke to them today.” He taps at his ear, “And the gods are always speaking to us ... but most cannot, or choose not, to hear. They bear closed minds and hearts that have been shut off to the divine. All they hear are their own desires echoing around inside the darkness of their souls. It takes much prayer and meditation to hear the whispers of the divine above our own wishful thoughts.”

dlgAnsw.text: “Why do people come to you then?”

dlgPart.npc_text: “Most folks that come to me, and yes they are few, come wanting to believe. They want to believe that the gods are still here, or if not here somewhere, paying attention to their miniscule existence. They look around and they see raiders and nobles who are hardly distinguishable. They grind themselves into the ground every day eeking out the barest survival. The only thing in abundance in this world seems to be hardship and suffering. They want to believe. Need it.”

dlgAnsw.text: “So you put on a show and give them some hope?”

dlgPart.npc_text: “No. I help them see the truth. Being surrounded by a world such as this, what do they think if they travel to see me and find an old man sitting without pomp or fanfare on a bare stone in the Waste? The arch is a holy site but they do not know that. And if I share with them the gods’ wisdom, as if in conversation with a neighbor at the tavern, wouldn’t they doubt the validity of my claims? Simple people want to believe that petitioning the gods is a life changing event. Old-man-on-rock-speaking-sagely does not look like the genuine article to them. So I give them a little of what they want so that they will receive what they need.”

dlgAnsw.text: “So the spectacle is false but the message is...”

dlgPart.npc_text: “...true. When we go to the gods for answers, they will answer. Sometimes it is difficult to hear them. It has taken me many years of meditation to hear their guidance. Still yet, it is not always easy. Their words swirl within us, in a dust storm of our own doubts, aspirations, and pride. But with focus one can bring the divine words to the fore and see them for what they are.”

dlgAnsw.text: “You seem so certain. How can you believe it?”

dlgPart.npc_text:
“I admit, it is not always easy. When you live your whole life communing with the gods and are always left guessing at their answers...even a great Oracle can feel lost. It shames me to admit it.”
He stares wistfully into the distance. “I think in the old days it was easier. The gods spoke and we heard with our ears, not our hearts. But I keep faith and do my best to tell others what I believe the gods are saying.”

dlgAnsw.text: “What do you know of this place? And the arch?”
“Do you not live in fear here in the Wastes?”
Leave.

dlgPart.npc_text:
“Fear of what? Starvation? We work hard to keep a modest crop. We use what little money we receive for buying basics from the rare traveling merchant. Or we occasionally make a visit to town for simple supplies. As you can probably guess our meals are meager but sufficient.
“Raiders? There’s hardly enough food or material value here to make it worth it for most raiders. It does happen though. They might take part of us as slaves. They may not. I’m the twenty sixth Oracle in four hundred years. Some of us even manage to die of old age, or so it is said. Some of us are taken. But what can we do? We are not warriors and we cannot leave our vigil. It is our duty to keep the holy ground and watch for the gods. Just as the soldier marches to battle knowing he may pay with his life, so do we stand watch at our post.”

dlgAnsw.text: “What do you know of this place? And the arch?”
“How is it that you can communicate with the gods even now?”
Leave.
